articles.headline: Trump’s Saudi Arabia Trip Figures Into Plan for Palestinian Deal
articles.snippet: Proponents of the president’s effort argue that recent shifts in the Arab world may have made the prospect of a regional peace less remote.
articles.abstract: Proponents of the president’s effort argue that recent shifts in the Arab world may have made the prospect of a regional peace less remote.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — For 15 years, Saudi Arabia has been pitching its formula for peace among Israel, the Palestinians and the Arab world, with little response from Israeli leaders.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Reveals Mounting Concern Over Trump Campaign and Russia
articles.snippet: John O. Brennan, the former director of the C.I.A., offered the fullest public account yet of how the federal investigation into Russian election meddling began.
articles.abstract: John O. Brennan, the former director of the C.I.A., offered the fullest public account yet of how the federal investigation into Russian election meddling began.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John O. Brennan, the former C.I.A. director, described on Tuesday a nerve-fraying few months last year as American authorities realized that the presidential election was under attack and feared that Donald J. Trump’s campaign might be aiding that fight.

articles.headline: Fox News Retracts Seth Rich Story That Stirred Controversy
articles.snippet: The family of Seth Rich objected after the network promoted a theory that Mr. Rich was killed because he shared D.N.C. emails with WikiLeaks.
articles.abstract: The family of Seth Rich objected after the network promoted a theory that Mr. Rich was killed because he shared D.N.C. emails with WikiLeaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News on Tuesday retracted a story linking the murder of a Democratic National Committee staff member with the email hacks that aided President Trump’s campaign, effectively quashing a conspiracy theory that had taken hold across the right-wing news media.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Daniel Victor

articles.headline: Uber to Repay Millions to Drivers, Who Could Be Owed Far More
articles.snippet: The company concedes taking tens of millions in excess commissions. But records point to improper tax deductions costing drivers even more.
articles.abstract: The company concedes taking tens of millions in excess commissions. But records point to improper tax deductions costing drivers even more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber said Tuesday that it had made a mistake in the way it calculated its commissions, at a cost of tens of millions of dollars to its New York drivers, and the company vowed to correct the practice and make the drivers whole for the lost earnings.

articles.headline: Divided Republicans May Find It Hard to Pass Any Budget
articles.snippet: The budget battle ahead is likely to mirror the party’s health care fight, in which concessions to moderates alienate conservatives and vice versa.
articles.abstract: The budget battle ahead is likely to mirror the party’s health care fight, in which concessions to moderates alienate conservatives and vice versa.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans greeted President Trump’s first full budget on Tuesday with open hesitation or outright hostility. But it was not clear that they could come up with an alternative that could win over conservatives and moderates while clearing a path for the tax cuts and policies they have promised for years.

articles.headline: When Colleges Dangle Money to Lure Students Who Ignored Them
articles.snippet: There is a May 1 deadline for students to choose a college and place a deposit, but increasingly, the negotiations continue well beyond that.
articles.abstract: There is a May 1 deadline for students to choose a college and place a deposit, but increasingly, the negotiations continue well beyond that.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the minds of parents and teenagers going through the college application process, May 1 is a magic date. At that point, you’ve sent in a deposit, bought a sticker for your car window and posted your choice on social media.

articles.headline: Amazon Sets Up Shop in the Heart of the Publishing Industry
articles.snippet: At physical bookstores like the new one opening in Manhattan this week, the company is drawing on its vast troves of customer data to shape the design.
articles.abstract: At physical bookstores like the new one opening in Manhattan this week, the company is drawing on its vast troves of customer data to shape the design.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, has often struck a defiant tone when asked about the company’s dominance of the book industry.

articles.headline: The Rise of the Fat Start-Up
articles.snippet: A service called Opendoor, which will make an offer on your house sight unseen, illustrates a new breed of start-up and Silicon Valley’s ever-widening ambitions.
articles.abstract: A service called Opendoor, which will make an offer on your house sight unseen, illustrates a new breed of start-up and Silicon Valley’s ever-widening ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, Keith Rabois, a longtime Silicon Valley investor and executive, had an ambitious idea: He wanted to start a website that would instantly offer a fair price for your home. If you accepted the offer, the site would agree to buy your house immediately, closing the deal in a matter of days.

articles.headline: Hunt for Manchester Bombing Accomplices Extends to Libya
articles.snippet: Developments indicated that the bomber, Salman Abedi, was part of a wider and more sophisticated plot than was initially believed.
articles.abstract: Developments indicated that the bomber, Salman Abedi, was part of a wider and more sophisticated plot than was initially believed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The police accelerated their hunt Wednesday for co-plotters of the Manchester concert bombing, making at least a half-dozen arrests in Britain, searching for a possible clandestine bomb factory and extending the investigation to Libya, where two of the bomber’s relatives were detained.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold, Stephen Castle and Suliman Ali Zway
